sp.speaker: Sp. & Ruf
sp.l: With all our heartes.

div.stage: Manent two Ladies the Lord and Knight: Felicia, and the two Wenches disguised, hide themselues.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Worthy Lord, doe not thinke immodestie in mee though contrarie to the bashfull habite of my sexe, I am inforc'd by loues almightie power, to reueale the secretes of my heart. Your Letters haue so much preuailed with mee, that in a worde I must confesse I loue you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Worthie Knight, I would my wordes had but the power so worke in you, that which your lines haue done in me, then should the happie consolation of my life dwell euer in your loues embracements.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Assure ye Ladie, your gift of loue to mee shall bee deserued, though nothing but my liues deare breath requite its.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: And I will rather die a shamefull death, then liue a hatefull life, which I must do vnlesse I find a meanes that may deserue your loue.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
No we your tongue goes like a well tuned Instrument, and makes my heart within my bosome daunce with ioy to heare such large requitall of my loue: but durst you to maintaine this your affection, although it
were with some daunger of your life?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Durst I? I vowe, euen by my soules eternitie, I durst.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Alas, if you knew all, t'is your owne good, not mine: and yet I lie, t'is my good too, since my life depends vpon your safetie.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: What is't deare Ladie? although it be the death of man, if it be pleasing vnto you Ile doo't.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: O let me embrace so deare a spirit in so deare a bosome: and since you haue bound your selfe by promise, I will be plaine, there are two that hate you two, because wee loue you, and often haue perswaded vs by giftes and large protestations to haue vs loue them if they kil'd you.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: What vs?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Who wee?

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Nay t'is too true; for while you liu'd, they said there was no hope for them to looke for any loue from vs: nowe wee poore sillie women, fearing least they without consent of vs, should doe that which their hatred doth intend, wee thinke it fitte preuention first be vsed, by giuing them to drinke of what themselues haue brude.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: First murther them.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: True, so shall ye then be sure,
T'inioy our loues, we yours, and liue secure.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: But what are they Ladies?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sparke.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And Ruffell.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: They die for't though they were my fathers sons.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: They shall not liue.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Let little children feare the shallow Brookes, for I can swim though't be through Seas of blood; let foolish feare goe dwell with women, for bloodie resolution shall not part from me, Ile kill them both euen with mine owne hands, Ile doo't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O no. Ile reueale it then, vnlesse you first do swear and take a Sacrament, what euer hap to keepe our names vntoucht.

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.p: Vntoucht? weele doo't.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Then for the meanes:

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Weele stabb them.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Weele fight with them.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: No, so you may misse them, and they kill you.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: Giue them a Figg.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Make them drinke their last.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Poyson them:

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.p: But for the meanes.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: You two shall make a banquet, and in a cuppe of Wine a health shall passe.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: In which ile mingle mingle such a dram, as they shall ride to heauen in post, vnlesse they misse the way.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: But where shall we get the poyson? because you knowe t'is daungerous, and will breede suspect where ere wee buy it.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: I haue a Countrey-man in towne an Apothecarie, one Signeur Aluino, a fellow that is well stor'd, and will sell me of the best.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: If a were of my minde, a would thinke no poyson too good for you.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.p: Come then, I would haue you goe about the preparation of the feast.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Now boyes, you haue a couple of goodly maisters,

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I Fleir, and thou hast a couple of vertuous Mistresses, O they are a couple of damn'd peeces, that will plot or counsell the death of two such worthie Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: For one of them the earth did neuer beare a worthier creature.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Which is that?

sp.speaker: Su,
sp.p: Which is that? Why sister, haue you so oft confest that his all perfection'd spirit poyntes him out for vertue herselfe to imitate, and yet doy' aske now which is that?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Howe? sister, nay now I smell you yfaith, doy' heare, doy' heare, whose Fidlers are you two? what Instruments do you beare I pra'y?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You haue tolde a wise tale, fayth fir wee carrie none.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: T'is true my little musitians, you carry but the cases my little curtals, yfaith I smell a smock heere too, and are you two wenches yfaith?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: If we were, I hope thou wouldest not wrong vs.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: No, as I am true Italian borne.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Then tis true, wee confesse to thee wee are both wenches, and the loue of these two Gentlemen, Sparke and Ruffel hath made vs leaue our selues to waite on them which by misfortune we did misse.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But beleeue me my little Gallants, yee play the Boyes well.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Well? why ile tell thee, I haue plaid the boy so long as I am chang'd into the nature of a boy, ile goe to span-counter with any page in Europe, for his best garters I can tell baudie tales, drinke drunke, brag, sweare, and lye with any Lackie in the towne.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: I can man a punck to a play, or slaunder any Gentlewoman as well as anie Innes a Court puny, I can as well as he, sweare such a Lady is in loue with me, and such a Cittizens Daughter would haue come to bed to mee, when all shall be as true as thy Ladies are honest.

sp.speaker: Na
sp.p: I wonder thoult liue in such a sinfull place.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Thy Ladies are as common as any Tauerne doore.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Good comparisons, for a man comes no sooner into a Tauerne, but hees welcome, and the operation of the pot makes him not able to stand when he comes out.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: But what shall we doe in this matter?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Doe? Why complaine them to the Magistrates, and preuent the murder.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: No, not so, ile tell you how't shall bee, harke in your eares.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.l: Doe it and we shall euer thanke thee.
Come lets about it then.

div.stage: Enter Signior Alunio the Apotheearie in his shop with wares about him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
What's this? O this is Arringus; this makes the old man able, and the young man lustie, strengthneth the
nerues & doth concoct the bloud, and her name is written on the box, because my wife should knowe it in my absence: this is Ciuet, this comes from the Cats taile, I would my were such a Cat: this perfumes your Ladies, and not without cause, for some, I meane whose sweet breath is dead, and teeth mourne in blacke for the losse on't this makes your young Gallants smell them nine daies before they see them, like young poops: this drug is pretious & deere; whats this? O this is the spirit of roses, nineteene bushels and a halfe of Roses make but an ounce, & a dram on't, tis made of the Quintessence of the water after the fifteenth distillation: none may kisse a Ladie after shee hath annointed her lips with this, vnder the degree of a Lord at least, tis worth nine poundes an ounce, yet I could neuer still it so.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Saue you Signior.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: Y'are welcome sir, what doe ye lacke?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I want a seruice, and am by my profession an Apothecarie, and shall be glad to be intertained by you.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: What countrie man art thou?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I am a Florentine borne.

sp.speaker: Alu,
sp.p: Thou art my Countrie man, and therefore welcom and in happie time, for I am bound for Italy, and want a man to take charge of my Shop, onely this is all: I shall require of you, bee carefull of your cares, and obedient to your Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I shall remember still not to forget what you giue me in charge.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Iacomo.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: Well Iacomo, if I finde thee honest thou shalt find me liberall.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I would be loath to be found otherwise.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: Continue so, I prethee, and so farwell Iaques, but ile enforme my wife before I goe to respect thee according to thy merrit.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Now come away my Customers, I hope I am fitted for an Apothecary s'hart I thinke ime turnd coniurer, for I haue no sooner cal'd, but the Deuils are appeared, what do yee lacke Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Where's your Maister fellow?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: My Maister is gone into Italie sir, but if you want any thing, ile vse you well, if you want any drugs to make Lotiums, any Restringent Powders, anie Aqua Mirabilis, any Cordiall receipts, or anie Pretious poysons?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: What poysons haue you?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Excellent good sir, as euer was tasted, looke you sir, this poysons by the smell, this by the sight, and this by the tastes.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Come giue mee some of this that poysons by the taste, but how must I vse it?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Put it into a little wine, and drinke it, twill bring you into a long sleepe.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But art sure twill poyson a man?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Am I sure on't? why tak't vpon my credit, twil poison any vermine, except it be a woman, for twill poyson a Cat sir.

sp.speaker: Kni,
sp.p: Why a Cat hath nine liues sir, and wilt not poyson a woman, seeing twill poyson a Cat?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: O no, why a woman hath nine Cats liues, a woman hath more liues then a horse hath diseases, and she wil bee sometimes in as many mindes in an houre, as shee has liues.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: What times are those?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: When shee's left a rich Marchants Widdow, commonly, and hath many suiters, she will in her minde marrie three or foure and fiftie of a'm in an afternoone, and threescore more, when she goes to bed, yet in the morning sheele haue none of them all, but goe to Church before day, and marry her Prentice for the good seruice a did her in her Husbands time.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Well, but whats the price of your poyson?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Theres an ounce will cost you a French crowne sir.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: Tis verie deere.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O sir tis verie cheape, considering the goodnesse on't.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yea? is there good in ill?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: O sir, I, in many thinges the better the worser.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: As in poyson, or in a punck, for the better whore the worser woman euer.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Well honest fellowe, there's thy money and farwell.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I thanke you sir, I haue sold you a poyson my old elders, twil make ani sleep indeede, and I thank God that's the worst twill doe, well, farwell Maister Apothecarie. I must now like a friend intreate your shop to haue a special care of it selfe.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: And shall wee dine with this Honorable Lord, & Knight to day?

sp.speaker: Spa,
sp.p: Theile take it vnkindely else.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Signior will you goe?

sp.speaker: Pet.,
sp.p: Not I, I was not bid.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Thats all one, shalt be my guest.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Come, a shall goe, for there will bee his Mistresse Madam Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Nay then I knowe the Iet of her complexion will draw the straw of his loue thither.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Faith I, poore Signior, I see the Springle of her beautie hath alreadie caught the Woodcocke of his affections.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Wel, I see he that wil haue the commoditie of good wits in his companie, must indure the discommoditie of ieastes, wit is like the heate of blood in youth 'twil breake out.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: True Signior, though it bee but on a Scab, but come shall we goe?

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: I my Heroique spirits, ile followe yee.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Petoune one way, and Nan the Page another way.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: O Signior Petoune, what newes?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Faith ill newes, the two Florentine Ladies, with Maister Sparke and Maister Ruffell were all poysoned yesterday at a feast by your Lord Piso and the Knight, but the Ladies haue recouered their health, but Sparke and Ruffell are dead, and their burial is committed to Fleire: your Lord & the Knight are committed to prison, & shal to morrow be arraign'd for the murther, and tride by the Ciuill-lawe, because your Lord is a stranger, and claimes to be tride by the law of nations.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Faith Signior I am very sorry for my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: I protest sir so am I for them both.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Well Signior ile commit you to God.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Let the whole band of Angels be centinells to your safetie sweet sir.

div.stage: Enter Fleire at one doore: and a Seruingman at another.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I pray sir doth Iustice Ferrio dwell heere?

sp.speaker: Ser,
sp.p: Yes sir a dwells heere.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Are you towards him sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I am a poore Gentleman, whose fortunes much depend vpon his fauours, and indeede sir I am his Clarke.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I pray sir your name.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: My name is Mittimus sir.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Good Maister Mittimus I would very willinglie speake with your Maister.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Indeede sir hee's not well, but if you please to send by me the substance of your busines I shall very carefullie deliuer it.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p:
Truely Maister Mittimus my businesse is but this: to morrow the Italian Lord, and Sir Iohn Haue-little are to
be araign'd, and your maister beeing the chiefe Iudge of the Court, without this presence or licence, the rest can do nothing: wherefore Doctor Caius intreates to know his pleasure in this businesse.

sp.speaker: Mitti:
sp.p: Sir I shall deliuer your message, and will returne his answere to you presently.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Good maister Mittimus therein shall you much obleige me to be thankfull.
sp.l: O all-directing power yeeld good aspect,
And to my purpose giue a blessed ende,
My intent is good, O let it so succeede,
And be auspicious still to each good deede.

sp.speaker: Ser:
sp.p: Sir my maister hath receiued your message, & hath sent this Ring as a token to Doctor Caius, desiring him, since my maisters health will not permit him to be present, to proceede alone to iudgement, and so commends his loue to him.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Good maister Mittimus, I shall both deliuer your maisters commendations, and the Ring.

div.stage: Enter Lord Piso with a Torch, a Night-cap, and his Doublet open: In prison.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Still tonguelesse night put off thy sable robe,
Thou needs not mourne, my villanies were done
sp.p: By day, thou hadst no hand in them, O I am great, as is a woman that is neare her time:
sp.l: And life's the burthen that I beare.
But t'is a bastard for that I am asha'md on't.
sp.p: The Law I hope is a skilfull midwife, and will soone deliuer me; grim Iustice doe thy worst,
sp.l: Thy crueltie shall prooue a curtesie,
And baile me out of prison.
sp.p: Lie there thou selfe-consuming Taper, true patern of my life, I haue consumde my selfe for others, as thou hast done for mee, and nowe shee has extinguisht my life as I this light.
sp.l: O how obedient was my bountie, still
To her commaund? my liberalitie
Did fatten mischiefe, and hath made her prowde:
O that too much of any thing shuld be so ill in euery thing
The Suns all seeng eye, with too much vntemperate heate makes wither what it made to flourish.
The earth being mother to all wholsome hearbes,
With too much fatnesse oft produceth weedes.
A sute of cloath doth keepe the bodie warme,
When richer garments makes the wearer proude.
O, the meanes the sweetest Musicke;
Contentment reuels when that string is toucht;
But O, the time will come she will repent
My death: for when she lookes on vices face
Vnmaske like mine; she will detest and loath it.
For this is truth and euermore hath bin,
None can forsake before he knowes his sinne.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Come, come, thou didst but dreame thou wert in hell.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: I tell thee I was in hell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And so was I too, Ile be sworne.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: And how long was't ere thou camest thither?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Me thought t'was long, as long as a suit hangs here in the Law ere it be ended.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: But I prethee how broad was the way to hell?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: As broad as the space between two lines in a Chauncerie bill.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O sir, there's the conscience on't, say the Plaintiffe be in one line, and the defendant in an other, they being enemies, wer't either conscience or honestie in the Clearke to thrust them no neare togither, that they might goe togither by th'eares? but yfaith what good fellowship was there in hell?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: O the diuels are excellent companions, theile drink your Dutch captains, or Court Ladies spunges.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Who didst see there?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Faith I saw the foure sonnes of Aymon, and they were Porters euer since there was a companie made of am.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Why are there a companie of Porters in hell?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: O I, the Diuels are but our Apes man.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: But didst thou see more of them that were damn'd?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yes, I sawe a Citizen damn'd for refusing a desperate debt, because t'was tendred him on a Sabboth.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I hope wee shall haue no more Citizens damn'd for that fault.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There was a poore mercinarie woman damn'd because shee forsooke her Trade, and turnd Puritane.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: And good reason, why coulde not shee haue kept her Trade, and beene a Puritane, as well as a Puritane keepe her Religion, and yet bee of her Trade?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There was a Ladie damn'd because shee neuer painted: a Puritane for saying Grace without turning vppe the white of his eyes: A Tailer for neuer hauing scabbie fingers: A Vintner for making greate two pennie-woorths of Sugar. But there was a Innes of Court man damn'd, and I was sorie for him.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Why was he damn'd?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Alas for a small fault.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I prethe what wast?

sp.speaker: Spar:
sp.p: For hauing alwayes money in his purse.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Were there no Lawyers in hell?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There were none of your great Lawyers as your Serieants, and Benchers, for they take counsaile of too manie good Angells to come there: but your young punie Lawyers, they were in swarmes like Gnats in Summer.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Why are there so manie of them there?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Alas man they seldom conuerse with a good Angell scarce once in a whole Michaelmasse Tearme, and if a come a stayes not long with am to feede these soules, for they are faine to sende am away strayght to
pay for the feeding of their Horses, there was a Chamber-maide damb'd for keeping her virginitie till shee was marryed, and there were many Soldiers damb'd for saying their prayers when they were drunke.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But what didst thou see in hell?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: O, I sawe a Scriuener damb'd for procuring a Gentleman money Gratis, but I came in an excellent time.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: What time was't?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: In a gossipping time, for Proserpina was newllie brought a bed of two twins.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Two twins! what were they?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: A Sergeant and a Yeoman, but shee has put them out to nurse.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I prithee where?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Faith at the Counter in Wood-street, and the slaues will sucke alreadie like little Horsleaches.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But when will she haue am home, that shee may be rid of am.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Faith shee's an vnnaturall Mother, shee cares not greatlie if they neuer come home, but the deuill their Father hee loues am well, heele haue am home againe ere long.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Which is the elder Brother?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: O the Sergeant, the Deuill allowes him the better maintenance, for hee has more to the dressing of his meate.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, since by the heauens pleasure I haue bin appointed to saue your liues, let mee intreate you to keepe your selues secret till the sequell of this action shall neede your presence.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Come lets goe, weele onely follow your directions.

div.stage: Enter two Iudges with their traine, and sit downe.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.p: Wil't please yee haue the prisoners brought foorth?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Wee can doe nothing till wee heare from Doctor Ferrio, to knowe his pleasure in these proceedings.

sp.speaker: 2. Iudges.
sp.p: Was any man sent to him?

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: Yes, Fleire, the Lady Floridaes man, which is not yet returned.

sp.speaker: Iaylor,
sp.p: Reuerend Iudges: heere's a Doctor at doore desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: Intreate him to come in.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Learned Doctors, Doctor Ferrio commends him to you, and because sicknesse hath laide so strong a hand vpon his weake decrepit bodye, which dooth detayne his presence, hee intreates you to accept of mee in his place, and as assurance of his earnest desire thereof, he has sent this well knowne ring as a token to you.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Sir, wee knowe the ring and you are verie welcome, and so I pra'y assume his place.

sp.speaker: Iaylor,
sp.p: Is it your pleasure the Prisoners be brought footh.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: I, both of them.

div.stage: Enter Piso Knight, two Ladies, two wenches, Nan and Sue, Petoune, Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: My Lord, you are heere indited of a hatefull crime, & I am verie sorry to see you in this sort stand here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Thrice Reuerend Iudges, and therefore honored Lords, I must confesse, that like a skilfull dancer, I haue truely footed folly, yet like a learner in my course of life, trod much out of measure, I haue liu'd like an vnbackt colt proud and wanton, my tree of life hath borne more leaues then fruite, I neuer was deboash'd & steard away my daies even in a sea of sinne.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: And in, that sea my Lord, you bore so great a saile as you haue ouer set your barke of life, and heere you are accused my Lord, euen of a hatefull crime, so is the Knight there for poisoning two Gentlemen, Sparke and Ruffell, how doe you answere this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, this is soone answered, for though that I haue surfeited on sinne, yet haue I not bin drunke with blood.

sp.speaker: Caius:
sp.p: What say you Knight?

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: The crime is great I must confesse my Lord, but I am sure the proofe can be but little.

sp.speaker: Cai:
sp.p: Ladies you know moste, and therefore tis fittest most you speake.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Why then my Lord, this is all we can say, this Lord and knight feasted diuers of vs their friendes, but foure of vs he drench'd with such a dramme which soone made two discharge the debt they owd to nature.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: O conscience wouldst thou giue me leaue!

sp.speaker: Fal:
sp.p: And wee no doubt my Lordes, had long ere this breath'd out our liues like them, but that we had the lesser quantisie, for being esteemed the weaker vessels, they thought the lesser blow would breake vs.

sp.speaker: Kni:
sp.p: O had not death arrested me.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Why then my Lord, wee thus must now proceede, they that spilt innocent blood themselues must bleed; but Ladies I haue heard you had a man cald Fleire, what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: He was sent to Doctor Ferrio, and we neuer saw him since.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Doe you know his hand Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I pray looke heere then.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: This is his hand indeede.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I very perfectly doe know it to be his.

sp.speaker: Fle
sp.p: Why then vppon this hand I heare arrest you both, vpon your liues.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Who, wee?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I, you Ladies, my Lord I pray you, reade this letter.

body.p: Reuerend Iudges, God wil by some meanes punish euerie sinne, and though against my will, yet by my conscience I am enforced to vnmaske my Ladies vilianies, the murther for which the Lord and Knight are like to die, was first plotted by them: the two Pages with my selfe did heare it: the Prisoners in this action, are inforc't by Sacrament to be secret, and thus intreating heauen in Iustice, still to ayde you.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.p: Is this true my Lord?

sp.speaker: 2, Iudg,
sp.p: They are sworne not to reueale it,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But being reueald they may affirme it.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: Tis too true my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Where are the Pages?

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: Heere my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: How say you boyes to this letter?

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: The letter speakes nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Wel Ladies, then we heere pronounce this sentence that you must die among the rest.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.l: You powers deuine, I know doe plainely see,
Heauens starrie eyes sees all our villanie:
And God in Iustice murther will reueale,
But were I now, my life for to beginne,
sp.p: Ide be an honest wife to you, wherefore forgiue me deerest Lord.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.l: Lady, I doe euen as I hope to be forgiuen.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Show mercy heauen, my sinnes doe thee offend,
Theres none can say hee's happie till his end;
Forgiuenesse Knight, and since the law on vs,
Hath laid so strickt a hand, O let me be
Thy wife before I die, and were I now
A thousand yeares to liue, I would be honest
Louing none but thee.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I doe forgiue you Lady with my soule.

div.stage: Enter a Messenger with Letters to Piso.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Long liue my honored Lord and mighty Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: So a will, as long as't please the Hang-man.

sp.speaker: Mes,
sp.p: My honored Lord, your Father is deceased, and the state of Florence by me hath sent their Letters and allegiance.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let them call backe the banisht Signior Antifront whome they & we, and al haue wrong'd: O could I liue but to inquire him out, in satisfaction of his wronges, ide marry his eldest Daughter, and whilst a liu'd a should be restored to his estate, but O hee's—

div.stage: Fleire showes himselfe to be Antifront,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.l: Heere my Lord.
I taxe you to your word, Signior Antifront yet liues,
And heeres his elder Daughter whome himselfe
But now condemn'd to die: and heeres the younger
Left for you, the poisoned men are heere a liue againe,
Who did but dreame of death, but yet doe
Liue t' enrich a nuptiall bed to you two,
And now since euerie thing so well doth sort,
Let all be pleas'd in this our comicke sport,
Where's Petoune? he shal haue his Mistris too,
He most deserues, for he did hotly woe,
If we part friendes, your hands vnto vs lend,
What was not well, weele next striue to amend.
